qas.question: Where are reserved matters stated in the Scotland Act?
If a matter is not specifically reserved, who is it devolved to?
Why do police and fire services fall under the purview of the Scottish Parliament?

answers.text: All matters that are not specifically reserved are automatically devolved to the Scottish Parliament

qas.question: How much can the SP alter income tax in Scotland?

answers.text: up to 3 pence in the pound
up to 3 pence in the pound
up to 3 pence in the pound

qas.question: Setting speed limits was one of the further devolutions which was conferred by what act?
What includes all subjects which are not stated in Schedule 6 to the Scotland Act?
Who does not have the ability to alter income tax in Scotland?
Who has the ability to alter income tax in Scotland by up to 33 pence?
The 2002 Act granted further fiscal devolution including what?

context: The <b5_0>specific devolved matters<b5_0/> are all subjects which are not explicitly stated in <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>Schedule 5<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> to the Scotland Act as reserved matters. <a2_2>All matters that are <a2_1>not specifically reserved<a2_1/> are <a2_0>automatically devolved<a2_0/> to <a1_2>the <a1_0><a1_1>Scottish Parliament<a2_2/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. Most importantly, this includes agriculture, fisheries and forestry, economic development, education, environment, food standards, health, home affairs, Scots law – courts, police and fire services, local government, sport and the arts, transport, training, tourism, research and statistics and social work. The <b6_0><b7_0>Scottish Parliament<b7_0/><b6_0/> has the ability to alter income tax in Scotland by <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>up to 3 pence in the pound<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. <a4_2>The <a4_0><a4_1>2012 Act<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> conferred further fiscal devolution including <b8_0>borrowing powers<b8_0/> and some other unconnected matters such as setting speed limits and control of air guns.
